skills_and_strengths.title: Station: Skills & strengths orientation
skills_and_strengths.content: If you have no idea what to do next, start with orientation. You can discover your interests, strengths and possible jobs through simple tests, short internships and career information. This step helps you choose a realistic path (school, training or preparation) instead of deciding randomly.

tips.activities: Think about activities you enjoy in everyday life (helping people, fixing things, computers, creativity).
tips.ask_people: Ask friends, teachers or family what they think you are good at.
tips.tests: Do short online career tests - they give ideas, not final decisions.
tips.internship: Try at least one short internship to see real work.
tips.videos: Watch job videos to understand daily tasks, not just job titles.
tips.notes: Write down what you liked and disliked after each experience.

steps.check_u: Take an online orientation test (e.g. Check-U).
steps.career_guidance: Make an appointment with career guidance (Berufsberatung).
steps.trial_internship: Ask your school about a trial internship (Praktikum).

you_dont_have_to_decide.title: You don't have to decide now
you_dont_have_to_decide.content: It is completely okay if you are not sure yet. You do not need one final life decision today. First explore, test small options, and then decide with more confidence.

tips.explore_first: Explore first: learn about different options before choosing one path.
tips.small_steps: Take small steps each week instead of waiting for the perfect plan.
tips.try_options: Try options in real life (internships, counseling, short courses).
tips.no_perfect_choice: There is no perfect first choice - you can adjust your direction later.
tips.combine_paths: You can combine paths (for example: learn German while doing an internship).
tips.decide_later: Decide later with better information, not under pressure.

steps.try_one_week: Test one option for 1-2 weeks and write down what you learned.
steps.talk_to_advisor: Talk to a counselor or trusted teacher to compare your options.

integration_courses.title: Integration courses
integration_courses.content: Integration courses help people who are new in Germany learn German and navigate daily life. They include a language course and an orientation course and are organized by BAMF with approved providers.

tips.structure: An integration course usually has two parts: language + orientation.
tips.placement_test: You usually take a placement test to find the right level.
tips.course_types: There are different course types: general, special and intensive courses.
tips.format: Courses can be attended full-time or part-time.
tips.costs: Participation is usually paid; fee exemptions can be possible in some cases.
tips.fee_exemption: Important: a fee exemption must be requested - it is not automatic.

lower_secondary_school_certificate.title: Lower secondary school certificate
lower_secondary_school_certificate.content: The lower secondary school certificate (Berufsreife) is an officially recognized German certificate, usually after grade 9. It is often the minimum requirement for vocational training.

tips.not_immediate: You don't have to finish your certificate immediately.
tips.many_paths: Many people first do BVJ, internships, jobs, and complete the certificate later.
tips.catch_up: If you didn't finish school yet, you can still catch up through several routes.
tips.recognition: If you have a Ukrainian certificate, it can often be officially recognized.

intermediate_secondary_school_certificat.content: The intermediate secondary certificate is a medium-level qualification in Germany (typically after grade 10). It supports access to vocational training and further school pathways.

tips.performance: School type alone does not decide the certificate - performance does.
tips.attendance: Attendance and participation matter a lot.
tips.key_subjects: Focus on German, Maths and English - key final exam subjects.
tips.recognition: Ukrainian school certificates may be officially recognized.
tips.parallel: Language learning and school qualification can run in parallel.

tips.online_possible: Some providers also offer online options.
tips.not_studienkolleg: Do not confuse this with Studienkolleg for international university entry.
tips.mv_schools: There are several evening schools/kollegs in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.
tips.requirements: Requirements often include prior schooling and work/life status criteria.

recognition_of_certificates.content: Recognition helps determine which German level your foreign certificate equals. It is often required for school pathways, vocational training and university applications.

tips.check_authority: Check the correct authority for your federal state and certificate type.

job_related_language_courses.title: Job-related Language Courses (BSK)
job_related_language_courses.content: Job-related language courses (BSK) help people with a refugee or migration background improve their German for work. They build on integration courses and are funded by BAMF.

tips.b1: Entry often requires around B1 German level.
tips.levels: There are certified levels from A2 up to C2 with workplace focus.
tips.format: Courses can be in-person or online.
tips.part_time: Many offers are full-time or part-time alongside work.
tips.costs: Participation is usually free; in some cases co-payment may apply.
tips.permit: Check early that you can get a participation permit.

steps.get_permit: First ask Jobcenter, Employment Agency or migration counseling (MBE/JMD) for a participation permit.
steps.documents: Bring your residence permit, registration and school/work certificates.
steps.placement_test: Do the placement test so the school can assign your level.
steps.attend: Attend regularly once the course starts.
steps.exam: Take the final exam (telc/DTB) after the course.

german_school_pathway.content: In Germany there are step-by-step school pathways. You can start with a lower or intermediate certificate and continue later toward higher qualifications like Abitur.

tips.certificate_helps: A German school certificate helps a lot for Ausbildung and jobs.
tips.catch_up: If you do not have a certificate yet, you can still catch up.
tips.realschule: Realschule is often a realistic and useful starting point.
tips.age: At 16-18, you are not too old to continue school routes.
tips.internships: Internships and motivation often matter more than perfect grades.
tips.recognition: If your foreign certificate is not recognized, there are still alternatives.

ukrainian_school_qualification.title: Ukrainian school qualification
ukrainian_school_qualification.content: After 9 years of school in Ukraine you usually receive a certificate comparable to the German lower secondary level. After 11 years you obtain a school-leaving certificate that can often be recognized in Germany at intermediate level. You can also continue the Ukrainian school pathway from abroad through supplementary classes, distance learning, or external examination.

tips.abroad_possible: A Ukrainian school certificate can be completed while living abroad.
tips.recognition_needed: Recognition procedures may still be required in Germany.

tips.simple_docs: Start with simple documents: CV, short message and your latest school certificate.

tips.ask_feedback: Ask for feedback when possible and improve your next application.

find_job.title: How to apply for a job
find_job.content: Applying for a job or apprenticeship in Germany usually requires a simple application: a short cover message, a CV (Lebenslauf) and sometimes school certificates. You do not need perfect German - companies mainly want to see motivation and reliability. You can prepare applications step by step and get help from teachers, advisors or digital tools.

tips.cv_simple: Keep your CV simple and clear - one page is enough at the beginning.
tips.mention_internships: Mention internships, school projects or helping activities (they count as experience).
tips.simple_german: Use simple German sentences; mistakes are normal.
tips.friendly_message: Write a short, friendly message explaining why you want the job.
tips.interview_questions: Prepare for questions like: Why this job? What are your strengths?
tips.review_before_send: Ask someone to read your application before sending it.
tips.rejections_normal: It is normal to receive rejections. Continue applying - success often comes after several tries.
tips.no_long_letters: Long formal letters are not required. Clear and friendly is better.

main.description: This guide will help you navigate your options in Germany. Whether you want to earn money, continue your education, or learn German, we have resources and step-by-step guidance for you. Choose the path that best fits your current situation and goals.

earn_money.title: Earn Money  Work & Career
earn_money.description: You want to earn money or gain your first work experience, but you are not yet sure which profession suits you? Here you will find pathways into work and careers  even without a perfect school certificate or with limited German skills. Whether it is a job, apprenticeship, internship or voluntary service: there are more options than you might think. We show you where to start and which steps make sense.

tips.no_need_for_plan: You do not need a perfect plan right away. Many paths begin with trying things out.
tips.practical_experience: Practical experience often matters more than certificates, especially at the beginning.
tips.german_skills: German language skills improve significantly through work and practical experience.
tips.low_age_opportunity: Even at the age of 16 or 17, there are legal opportunities to work or prepare for a career.

bvj_program.title: Pre-Vocational School Program (BVJ)
bvj_program.description: The Vocational Preparation Year (BVJ) is a one-year school programme for young people who do not yet have an apprenticeship or a clear career perspective. It combines lessons at a vocational school with practical work experience in companies. For young people who have recently migrated and have limited German skills, there is a specialised language-focused version called BVJ-S. The exact rules may vary slightly depending on the federal state. For detailed information, contact a vocational school or career counselling service.

tips.language_focus: Especially helpful if German skills are not yet sufficient for vocational training. Language learning and practical experience are well combined in BVJ-S.

bvj_s_program.title: Pre-Vocational School Program with Language Focus (BVJ-S)
bvj_s_program.description: The Vocational Preparation Year with Language Focus (BVJ-S) is a school-based programme at vocational schools in Germany. It is designed for newly arrived young people who have limited German language skills. The main goal of the BVJ-S is to improve German language skills and to support career orientation. Alongside language learning, students gain basic knowledge about working life and different professions. The programme combines intensive German as a second language (DaZ) lessons with practical activities and vocational orientation. Students can take part in practical training phases (internships) and learn how school, training and work in Germany function. The BVJ-S is a full-time educational programme and usually lasts one school year, depending on language level. It helps prepare students for the next step, such as vocational training, further schooling or other educational pathways.

abitur.title: Abitur / University entrance qualification
abitur.description: The Abitur is the highest school certificate in Germany. It gives you a general university entrance qualification  you can study at any university or college. Normally students get the Abitur at a Gymnasium (grade 12 or 13). But you can also complete it later as an adult (second education pathway). The final exam includes several written and oral exams. You do not always have to return to normal school  there are different options depending on your situation.

college_prep_adults.title: College-prep school for adults / evening grammar school
college_prep_adults.description: These are special schools for adults who want to get the German Abitur (university entrance qualification) later in life. You do not need to go back to a normal high school. There are two main versions: 'Kolleg' (full-time during the day, like a normal school, takes 2-3 years) and 'Abendgymnasium' (classes in the evening so you can work during the day, takes 3-4 years). After finishing, you can study at a university or start higher-level vocational training.

tips.common_pathway: This path is very common in Germany  many adults do their Abitur at 20-30 years old.
tips.prerequisites: You usually need the intermediate school certificate (Realschulabschluss/Mittlere Reife) first.

tips.financial_support: You may be eligible for student financial support (BAfG!).

have_idea.title: I have an idea/ a wish what I`d like to do - but how to get there?
have_idea.description: You already have an idea what you would like to do  that's great. Now the question is: what do you need to get there? Many careers in Germany follow clear steps (training -> work -> further qualification). Sometimes your goal is correct, but the path is different than expected. You might need a school certificate before you can start training. In Germany you often learn a job through dual training (company + vocational school). If your German is not strong yet, this does not mean you must give up the goal. You don't have to choose perfectly  you only need the next realistic step. You can change direction later. Many people do.

ukrainian_school_qualification.title: Ukrainian school qualification
ukrainian_school_qualification.description: After 9 years of schooling you receive a certificate comparable to the German lower secondary school certificate (Berufsreife/Hauptschulabschluss). After 11 years of schooling you obtain a Ukrainian school-leaving certificate that gives access to university in Ukraine and can USUALLY be recognised in Germany at least at the level of the intermediate secondary certificate (Mittlere Reife/Realschulabschluss). You want to obtain or complete a Ukrainian school certificate, even if you currently live in Germany? There are ways to continue the Ukrainian school pathway online or externally and obtain a state-recognised Ukrainian certificate. This pathway can be useful if you want to continue studying in Ukraine later or use a Ukrainian certificate for recognition procedures.

supplementary_classes.title: Supplementary classes
supplementary_classes.description: Supplementary classes (Ukrainian education component) are additional online lessons offered by a Ukrainian school while the student attends a regular German school. They do not replace regular schooling. In these supplementary classes, students mainly learn Ukrainian language, Ukrainian literature, and the history of Ukraine. Sometimes other subjects from the Ukrainian curriculum are also taught. These classes help students keep their Ukrainian language skills, reduce the learning load because not all subjects have to be studied twice, and can help with the recognition of school results. This type of learning can be useful for students who want to receive a Ukrainian school certificate.

tips.recognition_not_automatic: The recognition of grades does not happen automatically. Each [case needs verification].
tips.check_official_status: Make sure that the school is officially recognized by the state and is allowed to issue official Ukrainian school certificates.

distance_learning.description: Distance learning is a recognized form of education in Ukraine, even though classes do not take place at school. In distance learning, students take part in online classes on a regular basis. There is a fixed timetable. Assignments and tests are given regularly. The time required is similar to regular school education.

tips.stay_connected: You stay connected to the Ukrainian school system.

private_schools.title: Private schools
private_schools.description: Private schools are schools that are not fully paid by the government. You can get the same German school certificates at many private schools (Hauptschule, Realschule, sometimes Abitur). Some private schools are helpful for students who had problems in public school (language, moving countries, gaps in education). Many private schools offer support classes, German language help or smaller groups.

tips.prices_vary: Prices are very different. Some schools cost about 50  per month.
tips.not_easier: Important: A private school does NOT automatically make school easier. You still need to learn and pass exams.
tips.check_recognition: Always check if the school is officially recognised by the state. Otherwise the certificate may not be valid.
tips.beware_contracts: Beware of contracts: some schools require long-term payment even if you leave.

recognition_certificates.title: Recognition of certificates
recognition_certificates.description: A school certificate from another country can be recognized in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern as lower secondary school leaving certificate (Berufsreife) or intermediate school leaving certificate (Mittlere Reife). To do this, you must show that you successfully completed at least ten years at a general school. Your school certificate must also include grades in important subjects, such as your mother tongue, a foreign language, mathematics, a science subject, and a social studies subject. In Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, the Ministry for Education and Childcare is responsible for recognizing school certificates.

tips.application_method: The application for recognition must be sent by post (not by email). The application does not need a special form.
tips.incomplete_apps: Incomplete applications are the most common reason for long waiting times. It is better to submit too many documents than too few.
tips.official_certification: Make sure that all copies are officially certified.
tips.translation_requirement: School certificates from abroad must be translated into German by an official translator.
tips.cost_coverage: The costs for translations can be covered by the Jobcenter or the Employment Agency under certain conditions.

learn_german.title: Learn German
learn_german.description: Good German language skills are the key to school, vocational training and work in Germany. There are many ways to learn German - in courses, online or in everyday life. Here you will find an overview of useful ways to improve your German skills, no matter which level you start at.

tips.practice_over_grammar: Language is learned through practice - not only through grammar.
tips.combine_life_courses: Courses and everyday life can be combined well.
tips.free_offers: Many offers are free of charge or publicly funded.
tips.start_early: Even with limited German, it is worth starting early.
tips.work_improves_skills: German often improves faster when you work, do an internship or attend school.
tips.imperfect_okay: Good to know: You do not need to speak perfect German to take the next step.
tips.use_ai: Use AI to have texts explained or corrected for you.

integration_courses.title: Integration courses
integration_courses.description: Integration courses help people who are new to Germany to learn German and find their way in everyday life. They consist of a language course and an orientation course covering history, culture, laws and daily life in Germany. Integration courses are organised by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) and are offered by approved education providers.

tips.course_structure: An integration course always consists of a language course and an orientation course.
tips.placement_test: A placement test is carried out before the course starts to find the right level.
tips.course_types: There are different types of courses: general courses, special courses and intensive courses.
tips.attendance_mode: Courses can be attended full-time or part-time.
tips.ukrainian_refugees: Ukrainian refugees are not automatically obliged to attend, but may be required to participate.
tips.costs_fee: Participation is usually subject to a fee. Exemption from costs is possible under certain conditions.
tips.fee_exemption: Important: A fee exemption must be applied for - it does not apply automatically.

job_related_courses.title: Job-related Language Courses (BSK)
job_related_courses.description: Job-related language courses (BSK) help people with a refugee or migration background to improve their German language skills specifically for the workplace. They build on integration courses and are funded by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF). The aim is to support entry into training, employment or everyday working life through targeted language learning.

tips.b1_requirement: Job-related language courses usually require German language skills at least at B1 level at entry.
tips.course_variety: There are courses with certificate examinations (A2-C2) and workplace-related courses.
tips.format_options: Job-related language courses can take place in person or online.
tips.flexibility: Courses are available as full-time or part-time alongside employment.
tips.cost_rules: Participation is free of charge up to an annual taxable income of 20,000. If income is higher, a contribution may be required (can be covered by employer).
tips.participation_permit: Important: Check if you can get a participation permit  you cannot register without it. Available at Jobcenter, Employment Agency or migration counseling.

steps.contact_authority: First go to the Jobcenter, Employment Agency or a migration counseling office (MBE/MD) and ask for a job-related German course.
steps.check_permit: They will check if you can get a participation permit. If your German is below B1, you will usually be sent to an integration course first.
steps.choose_school: With the permit, choose a language school (course provider) near you.
steps.bring_docs: Bring your documents: residence permit, registration certificate (Anmeldung), school or work certificates.
steps.placement_test: The school will do a placement test and assign you to the right level (A2, B1, B2 or C1).
steps.attend_regularly: Wait for the course to start (often 2-6 weeks) and attend regularly  missing classes can cause problems with benefits.
steps.final_exam: After the course you take an official exam (telc or DTB) -> very important for training or employment.

vhs_learning_platform.title: VHS-learning platform
vhs_learning_platform.description: A Volkshochschule (VHS) is an adult education centre. Attendance is voluntary. Classes are in groups and there are many different courses. Besides language courses there are hobby courses (cooking, sports, art) and you can also earn their intermediate certificate (Realschulabschluss) or lower secondary certificate (Hauptschulabschluss). Classes depend on the centre and the course. Most offer morning and afternoon classes  ask directly at the centre. Fees vary depending on the course, centre and federal state. There is no single fixed price.

tips.advice: Where can I get advice? You can get information and personal counselling at your local adult education centre.
tips.language_interest: Interested in language courses? Check the sections Integration Course, Job-related Language Courses and Learn German.
tips.school_certificate: Do you want to gain or catch up a school certificate? See the sections Hauptschulabschluss, Realschulabschluss and Abitur. The section 'second-chance education' explains alternative ways.

tips.watch_costs: Pay attention to costs, subscriptions and advertising.

find_job.title: Find a job
find_job.description: Now you have the knowledge you need to take the next step and find your place in the German job market. Use the right job portals and be active. Every application helps you move forward. If you keep going, show initiative, and believe in yourself, your chances of finding a suitable job will increase.

tips.portal_focus: Each job portal has a different focus. Do not rely on just one platform.
tips.similar_positions: Do not search only for your job title, but also for similar positions. Some jobs have different names in Germany than in your home country.
tips.support_services: Use the support services offered by the Jobcenter and the Federal Employment Agency.
tips.hidden_market: Many jobs are not posted online. Asking employers directly can often lead to better results than online applications.
tips.internships: Also consider internships or trial work. Very often, this can lead to a permanent job.
tips.apply_anyway: Apply even if you do not meet 100% of the requirements.
tips.track_applications: Keep a list of your applications so you can easily see where you have already applied.

steps.use_ai: Use AI tools to create CV templates and cover letters.
steps.adapt_cv: Adapt your CV and cover letter to each job you apply for.
steps.search_routine: Search for new job openings two to three times per week and respond to any feedback or replies.
